eaves, because they are lecherous. The Duke yet
would have dark deeds darkly answered. He would
never bring them to light Would he were returned.
Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing.
Farewell, good friar. I prithee pray for me. The
Duke, I say to thee again, would eat mutton on
Fridays. He’s now past it, yet— and I say to thee—
he would mouth with a beggar though she smelt
brown bread and garlic. Say that I said so. Farewell.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: No might nor greatness in mortality
Can censure scape. Back-wounding calumny
The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong
Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?
But who comes here?

div.stage: Enter Escalus, Provost, Officers, and Mistress Overdone, a Bawd.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: Go, away with her to prison.

sp.speaker: BAWD
sp.p:
Good my lord, be good to me. Your Honor is
accounted a merciful man, good my lord.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit
in the same kind? This would make mercy
swear and play the tyrant.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
A bawd of eleven years’ continuance, may it
please your Honor.

sp.speaker: BAWD
sp.p:
My lord, this is one Lucio’s information
against me. Mistress Kate Keepdown was
with child by him in the Duke’s time; he promised
her marriage. His child is a year and a quarter old
come Philip and Jacob. I have kept it myself, and see
how he goes about to abuse me.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
That fellow is a fellow of much license. Let
him be called before us. Away with her to prison.—
Go to, no more words.

Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered.
Claudio must die tomorrow. Let him be furnished
with divines and have all charitable preparation. If
my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so
with him.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
So please you, this friar hath been with him,
and advised him for th’ entertainment of death.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: Good even, good father.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Bliss and goodness on you.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: Of whence are you?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Not of this country, though my chance is now
To use it for my time. I am a brother
Of gracious order, late come from the See
In special business from his Holiness.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: What news abroad i’ th’ world?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
None but that there is so great a fever
on goodness that the dissolution of it must cure it.
Novelty is only in request, and it is as dangerous to
be aged in any kind of course as it is virtuous to be
constant in any undertaking. There is scarce truth
enough alive to make societies secure, but security
enough to make fellowships accursed. Much upon
this riddle runs the wisdom of the world. This news
is old enough, yet it is every day’s news. I pray you,
sir, of what disposition was the Duke?

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
One that, above all other strifes, contended
especially to know himself.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: What pleasure was he given to?

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Rather rejoicing to see another merry than
merry at anything which professed to make him
rejoice— a gentleman of all temperance. But leave
we him to his events, with a prayer they may prove
prosperous, and let me desire to know how you find
Claudio prepared. I am made to understand that
you have lent him visitation.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
He professes to have received no
sinister measure from his judge but most willingly
humbles himself to the determination of justice. Yet
had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his
frailty, many deceiving promises of life, which I, by
my good leisure, have discredited to him, and now
is he resolved to die.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
You have paid the heavens your function and
the prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have
labored for the poor gentleman to the extremest
shore of my modesty, but my brother justice have I
found so severe that he hath forced me to tell him
he is indeed Justice.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
If his own life answer the straitness of
his proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if
he chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Peace be with you.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: He who the sword of heaven will bear
Should be as holy as severe,
Pattern in himself to know,
Grace to stand, and virtue go;
More nor less to others paying
Than by self-offenses weighing.
Shame to him whose cruel striking
Kills for faults of his own liking.
Twice treble shame on Angelo,
To weed my vice, and let his grow.
O, what may man within him hide,
Though angel on the outward side!
How may likeness made in crimes,
Making practice on the times,
To draw with idle spiders’ strings
Most ponderous and substantial things.
Craft against vice I must apply.
With Angelo tonight shall lie
His old betrothèd but despisèd.
So disguise shall, by th’ disguisèd,
Pay with falsehood false exacting
And perform an old contracting.

lg.l: Take, O take those lips away,
And those eyes, the break of day,
Lights that do mislead the morn.
But my kisses bring again, bring again,
Seals of love, but sealed in vain, sealed in vain.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Break off thy song and haste thee quick away.
Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice
Hath often stilled my brawling discontent.
I cry you mercy, sir, and well could wish
You had not found me here so musical.
Let me excuse me, and believe me so,
My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: ’Tis good, though music oft hath such a charm
To make bad good and good provoke to harm.
sp.p:
I pray you tell me, hath anybody inquired for me
here today? Much upon this time have I promised
here to meet.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.p:
You have not been inquired after. I have sat
here all day.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
I do constantly believe you. The time is
come even now. I shall crave your forbearance a
little. Maybe I will call upon you anon for some
advantage to yourself.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: I am always bound to you.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Very well met, and welcome.
What is the news from this good deputy?

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: He hath a garden circummured with brick,
Whose western side is with a vineyard backed;
And to that vineyard is a planchèd gate
That makes his opening with this bigger key.
This other doth command a little door
Which from the vineyard to the garden leads.
There have I made my promise, upon the
Heavy middle of the night, to call upon him.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: I have ta’en a due and wary note upon ’t.
With whispering and most guilty diligence,
In action all of precept, he did show me
The way twice o’er.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Are there no other tokens
Between you ’greed concerning her observance?

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: No, none, but only a repair i’ th’ dark,
And that I have possessed him my most stay
Can be but brief, for I have made him know
I have a servant comes with me along
That stays upon me, whose persuasion is
I come about my brother.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: ’Tis well borne up.
I have not yet made known to Mariana
A word of this.— What ho, within; come forth.
To Mariana. I pray you be acquainted with this maid.
She comes to do you good.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: I do desire the like.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Good friar, I know you do, and have found it.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Take then this your companion by the hand,
Who hath a story ready for your ear.
I shall attend your leisure. But make haste.
The vaporous night approaches.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Will ’t please you walk aside?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: O place and greatness, millions of false eyes
Are stuck upon thee; volumes of report
Run with these false, and, most contrarious, quest
Upon thy doings; thousand escapes of wit
Make thee the father of their idle dream
And rack thee in their fancies.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Welcome. How agreed?

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: She’ll take the enterprise upon her, father,
If you advise it.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: It is not my consent
But my entreaty too.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Little have you to say
When you depart from him, but, soft and low,
“ Remember now my brother.”

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all.
He is your husband on a precontract.
To bring you thus together ’tis no sin,
Sith that the justice of your title to him
Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go.
Our corn’s to reap, for yet our tithe’s to sow.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
Come hither, sirrah. Can you cut off a man’s
head?

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be
a married man, he’s his wife’s head, and I can never
cut off a woman’s head.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield
me a direct answer. Tomorrow morning are to die
Claudio and Barnardine. Here is in our prison a
common executioner, who in his office lacks a
helper. If you will take it on you to assist him, it
shall redeem you from your gyves; if not, you shall
have your full time of imprisonment and your
deliverance with an unpitied whipping, for you have
been a notorious bawd.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of
mind, but yet I will be content to be a lawful
hangman. I would be glad to receive some instruction
from my fellow partner.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
What ho, Abhorson!— Where’s Abhorson
there?

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: Do you call, sir?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
Sirrah, here’s a fellow will help you tomorrow
in your execution. If you think it meet, compound
with him by the year and let him abide here
with you; if not, use him for the present and dismiss
him. He cannot plead his estimation with you; he
hath been a bawd.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p:
A bawd, sir? Fie upon him! He will discredit
our mystery.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
Go to, sir; you weigh equally. A feather will
turn the scale.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Pray, sir, by your good favor— for surely, sir, a
good favor you have, but that you have a hanging
look— do you call, sir, your occupation a mystery?

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: Ay, sir, a mystery.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery;
and your whores, sir, being members of my occupation,
using painting, do prove my occupation a
mystery; but what mystery there should be in hanging,
if I should be hanged, I cannot imagine.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: Sir, it is a mystery.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p: Proof?

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p:
Every true man’s apparel fits your thief. If it
be too little for your thief, your true man thinks it
big enough; if it be too big for your thief, your thief
thinks it little enough. So every true man’s apparel
fits your thief.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: Are you agreed?

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Sir, I will serve him, for I do find your hangman
is a more penitent trade than your bawd. He
doth oftener ask forgiveness.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
You, sirrah, provide your block
and your axe tomorrow, four o’clock.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p:
Come on, bawd. I will instruct
thee in my trade. Follow.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
I do desire to learn, sir; and I hope, if you have
occasion to use me for your own turn, you shall find
me yare. For truly, sir, for your kindness, I owe
you a good turn.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Call hither Barnardine and Claudio.
Th’ one has my pity; not a jot the other,
Being a murderer, though he were my brother.
Look, here’s the warrant, Claudio, for thy death.
’Tis now dead midnight, and by eight tomorrow
Thou must be made immortal. Where’s Barnardine?

sp.speaker: CLAUDIO
sp.l: As fast locked up in sleep as guiltless labor
When it lies starkly in the traveler’s bones.
He will not wake.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Who can do good on him?
Well, go, prepare yourself. Knock within. But hark, what noise?—
Heaven give your spirits comfort.
By and by!—
I hope it is some pardon or reprieve
For the most gentle Claudio.
Welcome, father.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: The best and wholesom’st spirits of the night
Envelop you, good provost. Who called here of late?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: None since the curfew rung.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Not Isabel?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: They will, then, ere ’t be long.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: What comfort is for Claudio?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: There’s some in hope.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: It is a bitter deputy.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Not so, not so. His life is paralleled
Even with the stroke and line of his great justice.
He doth with holy abstinence subdue
That in himself which he spurs on his power
To qualify in others. Were he mealed with that
Which he corrects, then were he tyrannous,
But this being so, he’s just. Knock within. Now are they come.
This is a gentle provost. Seldom when
The steelèd jailer is the friend of men.
How now, what noise? That spirit’s possessed with haste
That wounds th’ unsisting postern with these strokes.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: There he must stay until the officer
Arise to let him in. He is called up.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Have you no countermand for Claudio yet,
But he must die tomorrow?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: None, sir, none.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: As near the dawning, provost, as it is,
You shall hear more ere morning.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Happily
You something know, yet I believe there comes
No countermand. No such example have we.
Besides, upon the very siege of justice
Lord Angelo hath to the public ear
Professed the contrary.
This is his Lordship’s man.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: And here comes Claudio’s pardon.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.p:
My lord hath sent
you this note, and by me this further charge: that
you swerve not from the smallest article of it,
neither in time, matter, or other circumstance.
Good morrow, for, as I take it, it is almost day.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: I shall obey him.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This is his pardon, purchased by such sin
For which the pardoner himself is in.
Hence hath offense his quick celerity
When it is borne in high authority.
When vice makes mercy, mercy’s so extended
That for the fault’s love is th’ offender friended.
As Friar. Now, sir, what news?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
I told you: Lord Angelo, belike thinking me
remiss in mine office, awakens me with this unwonted
putting-on, methinks strangely; for he hath
not used it before.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Pray you let’s hear.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.q:
Whatsoever you may hear to the contrary, let Claudio
be executed by four of the clock, and in the afternoon
Barnardine. For my better satisfaction, let me have
Claudio’s head sent me by five. Let this be duly
performed with a thought that more depends on it
than we must yet deliver. Thus fail not to do your
office, as you will answer it at your peril.
What say you to this, sir?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
What is that Barnardine who is to be
executed in th’ afternoon?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
A Bohemian born, but here nursed up and
bred; one that is a prisoner nine years old.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
How came it that the absent duke had
not either delivered him to his liberty, or executed
him? I have heard it was ever his manner to do so.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
DUKE
sp.p: It is now apparent?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: Most manifest, and not denied by himself.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Hath he borne himself penitently in
prison? How seems he to be touched?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully
but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and
fearless of what’s past, present, or to come; insensible
of mortality and desperately mortal.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: He wants advice.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
He will hear none. He hath evermore had the
liberty of the prison; give him leave to escape
hence, he would not. Drunk many times a day, if not
many days entirely drunk. We have very oft awaked
him, as if to carry him to execution, and showed
him a seeming warrant for it. It hath not moved him
at all.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
More of him anon. There is written in
your brow, provost, honesty and constancy; if I read
it not truly, my ancient skill beguiles me. But in the
boldness of my cunning, I will lay myself in hazard.
Claudio, whom here you have warrant to execute, is
no greater forfeit to the law than Angelo, who hath
sentenced him. To make you understand this in a
manifested effect, I crave but four days’ respite, for
the which you are to do me both a present and a
dangerous courtesy.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: Pray, sir, in what?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: In the delaying death.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
Alack, how may I do it, having the hour
limited, and an express command, under penalty,
to deliver his head in the view of Angelo? I may
make my case as Claudio’s, to cross this in the
smallest.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
By the vow of mine order I warrant
you, if my instructions may be your guide. Let this
Barnardine be this morning executed and his head
borne to Angelo.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p:
Angelo hath seen them both and will discover
the favor.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
O, death’s a great disguiser, and you
may add to it. Shave the head and tie the beard, and
say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared
before his death. You know the course is common.
If anything fall to you upon this, more than thanks
and good fortune, by the saint whom I profess, I
will plead against it with my life.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: Pardon me, good father, it is against my oath.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Were you sworn to the Duke or to the
Deputy?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: To him and to his substitutes.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
You will think you have made no
offense if the Duke avouch the justice of your
dealing?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: But what likelihood is in that?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Not a resemblance, but a certainty; yet
since I see you fearful, that neither my coat, integrity,
nor persuasion can with ease attempt you, I will
go further than I meant, to pluck all fears out of
you. Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal of the
Duke. He shows the Provost a paper. You know the
character, I doubt not, and the signet is not strange
to you.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.p: I know them both.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
The contents of this is the return of the
Duke; you shall anon overread it at your pleasure,
where you shall find within these two days he will
be here. This is a thing that Angelo knows not, for
he this very day receives letters of strange tenor,
perchance of the Duke’s death, perchance entering
into some monastery, but by chance nothing of
what is writ. Look, th’ unfolding star calls up the
shepherd. Put not yourself into amazement how
these things should be. All difficulties are but easy
when they are known. Call your executioner, and
off with Barnardine’s head. I will give him a present
shrift, and advise him for a better place. Yet you are
amazed, but this shall absolutely resolve you.
sp.stage: He gives the Provost the paper.
sp.p: Come away; it is almost clear dawn.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
I am as well acquainted here as I was in our
house of profession. One would think it were Mistress
Overdone’s own house, for here be many of
her old customers. First, here’s young Master Rash.
He’s in for a commodity of brown paper and old
ginger, ninescore and seventeen pounds, of which
he made five marks ready money. Marry, then
ginger was not much in request, for the old women
were all dead. Then is there here one Master Caper,
at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer, for some
four suits of peach-colored satin, which now
peaches him a beggar. Then have we here young
Dizzy and young Master Deep-vow, and Master
Copper-spur and Master Starve-lackey the rapier-and-dagger
man, and young Drop-heir that killed
lusty Pudding, and Master Forth-light the tilter, and
brave Master Shoe-tie the great traveler, and wild
Half-can that stabbed Pots, and I think forty more,
all great doers in our trade, and are now “ for the
Lord’s sake.”

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Master Barnardine, you must rise
and be hanged, Master Barnardine.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: What ho, Barnardine!

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
A pox o’ your throats! Who makes
that noise there? What are you?

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Your friends,
sir, the hangman. You must be so good, sir, to rise
and be put to death.

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
Away, you rogue, away! I am
sleepy.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p:
Tell him he must awake, and
that quickly too.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till
you are executed, and sleep afterwards.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
He is coming, sir, he is coming. I hear his
straw rustle.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p: Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p: Very ready, sir.

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
How now, Abhorson? What’s the news
with you?

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p:
Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into
your prayers, for, look you, the warrant’s come.

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
You rogue, I have been drinking all night.
I am not fitted for ’t.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.p:
O, the better, sir, for he that drinks all night
and is hanged betimes in the morning may sleep the
sounder all the next day.

sp.speaker: ABHORSON
sp.p:
Look you, sir, here comes
your ghostly father. Do we jest now, think you?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Sir, induced by my
charity, and hearing how hastily you are to depart, I
am come to advise you, comfort you, and pray with
you.

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
Friar, not I. I have been drinking hard all
night, and I will have more time to prepare me, or
they shall beat out my brains with billets. I will not
consent to die this day, that’s certain.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
O, sir, you must. And therefore I
beseech you look forward on the journey you shall
go.

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
I swear I will not die today for any man’s
persuasion.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: But hear you—

sp.speaker: BARNARDINE
sp.p:
Not a word. If you have anything to say to
me, come to my ward, for thence will not I today.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Unfit to live or die. O gravel heart!
After him, fellows; bring him to the block.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: A creature unprepared, unmeet for death,
And to transport him in the mind he is
Were damnable.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Here in the prison, father,
There died this morning of a cruel fever
One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate,
A man of Claudio’s years, his beard and head
Just of his color. What if we do omit
This reprobate till he were well inclined,
And satisfy the Deputy with the visage
Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: O, ’tis an accident that heaven provides!
Dispatch it presently. The hour draws on
Prefixed by Angelo. See this be done
And sent according to command, whiles I
Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: This shall be done, good father, presently.
But Barnardine must die this afternoon,
And how shall we continue Claudio,
To save me from the danger that might come
If he were known alive?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Let this be done:
Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio.
Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting
To yonder generation, you shall find
Your safety manifested.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: I am your free dependent.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Now will I write letters to Angelo—
The Provost he shall bear them— whose contents
Shall witness to him I am near at home
And that by great injunctions I am bound
To enter publicly. Him I’ll desire
To meet me at the consecrated fount
A league below the city; and from thence,
By cold gradation and well-balanced form,
We shall proceed with Angelo.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Here is the head. I’ll carry it myself.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Convenient is it. Make a swift return,
For I would commune with you of such things
That want no ear but yours.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: I’ll make all speed.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Peace, ho, be here.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: The tongue of Isabel. She’s come to know
If yet her brother’s pardon be come hither.
But I will keep her ignorant of her good
To make her heavenly comforts of despair
When it is least expected.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Ho, by your leave.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: The better, given me by so holy a man.
Hath yet the Deputy sent my brother’s pardon?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: He hath released him, Isabel, from the world.
His head is off, and sent to Angelo.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Nay, but it is not so.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: It is no other.
Show your wisdom, daughter, in your close patience.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: You shall not be admitted to his sight.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Unhappy Claudio, wretched Isabel,
Injurious world, most damnèd Angelo!

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot.
Forbear it, therefore; give your cause to heaven.
Mark what I say, which you shall find
By every syllable a faithful verity.
The Duke comes home tomorrow— nay, dry your eyes.
One of our convent, and his confessor,
Gives me this instance. Already he hath carried
Notice to Escalus and Angelo,
Who do prepare to meet him at the gates,
There to give up their power. If you can, pace your wisdom
In that good path that I would wish it go,
And you shall have your bosom on this wretch,
Grace of the Duke, revenges to your heart,
And general honor.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: I am directed by you.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.stage: , as Friar, showing her a paper
sp.l: This letter, then, to Friar Peter give.
’Tis that he sent me of the Duke’s return.
Say, by this token, I desire his company
At Mariana’s house tonight. Her cause and yours
I’ll perfect him withal, and he shall bring you
Before the Duke, and to the head of Angelo
Accuse him home and home. For my poor self,
I am combinèd by a sacred vow
And shall be absent. Wend you with this letter.
Command these fretting waters from your eyes
With a light heart. Trust not my holy order
If I pervert your course.— Who’s here?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: Good even, friar, where’s the Provost?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Not within, sir.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
O, pretty Isabella, I am pale at mine heart to see
thine eyes so red. Thou must be patient. I am fain to
dine and sup with water and bran. I dare not for my
head fill my belly. One fruitful meal would set me to
’t. But they say the Duke will be here tomorrow. By
my troth, Isabel, I loved thy brother. If the old
fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home,
he had lived.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Sir, the Duke is marvelous little beholding
to your reports, but the best is, he lives not
in them.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Friar, thou knowest not the Duke so well as I do.
He’s a better woodman than thou tak’st him for.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Well, you’ll answer this one day. Fare
you well.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Nay, tarry, I’ll go along with thee. I can tell thee
pretty tales of the Duke.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
You have told me too many of him
already, sir, if they be true; if not true, none were
enough.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
I was once before him for getting a wench with
child.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Did you such a thing?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Yes, marry, did I, but I was fain to forswear it.
They would else have married me to the rotten
medlar.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Sir, your company is fairer than honest.
Rest you well.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
By my troth, I’ll go with thee to the lane’s end. If
bawdy talk offend you, we’ll have very little of it.
Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr. I shall stick.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched
other.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.p:
In most uneven and distracted manner. His
actions show much like to madness. Pray heaven his
wisdom be not tainted. And why meet him at the
gates and deliver our authorities there?

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: I guess not.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.p:
And why should we proclaim it in an hour
before his entering, that if any crave redress of
injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the
street?

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch
of complaints, and to deliver us from devices
hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand
against us.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.p:
Well, I beseech you let it be proclaimed.
Betimes i’ th’ morn, I’ll call you at your house. Give
notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet
him.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: I shall, sir. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: Good night.
This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant
And dull to all proceedings. A deflowered maid,
And by an eminent body that enforced
The law against it. But that her tender shame
Will not proclaim against her maiden loss,
How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no,
For my authority bears of a credent bulk
That no particular scandal once can touch
But it confounds the breather. He should have lived,
Save that his riotous youth with dangerous sense
Might in the times to come have ta’en revenge
By so receiving a dishonored life
With ransom of such shame. Would yet he had lived.
Alack, when once our grace we have forgot,
Nothing goes right. We would, and we would not.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: These letters at fit time deliver me.
The Provost knows our purpose and our plot.
The matter being afoot, keep your instruction
And hold you ever to our special drift,
Though sometimes you do blench from this to that
As cause doth minister. Go call at Flavius’ house
And tell him where I stay. Give the like notice
To Valencius, Rowland, and to Crassus,
And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate.
But send me Flavius first.

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: It shall be speeded well.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: I thank thee, Varrius. Thou hast made good haste.
Come, we will walk. There’s other of our friends
Will greet us here anon. My gentle Varrius.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: To speak so indirectly I am loath.
I would say the truth, but to accuse him so
That is your part; yet I am advised to do it,
He says, to veil full purpose.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Be ruled by him.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Besides, he tells me that, if peradventure
He speak against me on the adverse side,
I should not think it strange, for ’tis a physic
That’s bitter to sweet end.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: I would Friar Peter—

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O peace, the Friar is come.

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: Come, I have found you out a stand most fit,
Where you may have such vantage on the Duke
He shall not pass you. Twice have the trumpets sounded.
The generous and gravest citizens
Have hent the gates, and very near upon
The Duke is entering. Therefore hence, away.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Duke, Varrius, Lords, Angelo, Escalus, Lucio, Provost, Officers, and Citizens at several doors.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: My very worthy cousin, fairly met.
To Escalus. Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.

sp.speaker: ANGELO, ESCALUS
sp.l: Happy return be to your royal Grace.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Many and hearty thankings to you both.
We have made inquiry of you, and we hear
Such goodness of your justice that our soul
Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks,
Forerunning more requital.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: You make my bonds still greater.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: O, your desert speaks loud, and I should wrong it
To lock it in the wards of covert bosom
When it deserves with characters of brass
A forted residence ’gainst the tooth of time
And razure of oblivion. Give me your hand
And let the subject see, to make them know
That outward courtesies would fain proclaim
Favors that keep within.— Come, Escalus,
You must walk by us on our other hand.
And good supporters are you.

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: Now is your time. Speak loud, and kneel before him.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Justice, O royal duke. Vail your regard
Upon a wronged— I would fain have said, a maid.
O worthy prince, dishonor not your eye
By throwing it on any other object
Till you have heard me in my true complaint
And given me justice, justice, justice, justice.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Relate your wrongs. In what, by whom? Be brief.
Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice.
Reveal yourself to him.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O worthy duke,
You bid me seek redemption of the devil.
Hear me yourself, for that which I must speak
Must either punish me, not being believed,
Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm.
She hath been a suitor to me for her brother
Cut off by course of justice.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: By course of justice!

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Most strange, but yet most truly will I speak.
That Angelo’s forsworn, is it not strange?
That Angelo’s a murderer, is ’t not strange?
That Angelo is an adulterous thief,
An hypocrite, a virgin-violator,
Is it not strange, and strange?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Nay, it is ten times strange.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: It is not truer he is Angelo
Than this is all as true as it is strange.
Nay, it is ten times true, for truth is truth
To th’ end of reck’ning.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Away with her. Poor soul,
She speaks this in th’ infirmity of sense.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believest
There is another comfort than this world,
That thou neglect me not with that opinion
That I am touched with madness. Make not impossible
That which but seems unlike. ’Tis not impossible
But one, the wicked’st caitiff on the ground,
May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute
As Angelo. Even so may Angelo,
In all his dressings, caracts, titles, forms,
Be an archvillain. Believe it, royal prince,
If he be less, he’s nothing, but he’s more,
Had I more name for badness.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: By mine honesty,
If she be mad— as I believe no other—
Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense,
Such a dependency of thing on thing,
As e’er I heard in madness.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O gracious duke,
Harp not on that; nor do not banish reason
For inequality, but let your reason serve
To make the truth appear where it seems hid,
And hide the false seems true.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Many that are not mad
Have, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say?

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: I am the sister of one Claudio,
Condemned upon the act of fornication
To lose his head, condemned by Angelo.
I, in probation of a sisterhood,
Was sent to by my brother; one Lucio
As then the messenger—

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: That’s I, an ’t like your Grace.
I came to her from Claudio and desired her
To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo
For her poor brother’s pardon.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: That’s he indeed.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: You were not bid to speak.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: No, my good lord,
Nor wished to hold my peace.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: I wish you now, then.
Pray you take note of it, and when you have
A business for yourself, pray heaven you then
Be perfect.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: I warrant your Honor.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: The warrant’s for yourself. Take heed to ’t.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: This gentleman told somewhat of my tale.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: It may be right, but you are i’ the wrong
To speak before your time.— Proceed.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: I went
To this pernicious caitiff deputy—

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: That’s somewhat madly spoken.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Pardon it;
The phrase is to the matter.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Mended again. The matter; proceed.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: In brief, to set the needless process by:
How I persuaded, how I prayed and kneeled,
How he refelled me, and how I replied—
For this was of much length— the vile conclusion
I now begin with grief and shame to utter.
He would not, but by gift of my chaste body
To his concupiscible intemperate lust,
Release my brother; and after much debatement,
My sisterly remorse confutes mine honor,
And I did yield to him. But the next morn betimes,
His purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrant
For my poor brother’s head.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This is most likely!

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O, that it were as like as it is true!

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: By heaven, fond wretch, thou know’st not what thou speak’st,
Or else thou art suborned against his honor
In hateful practice. First, his integrity
Stands without blemish; next, it imports no reason
That with such vehemency he should pursue
Faults proper to himself. If he had so offended,
He would have weighed thy brother by himself
And not have cut him off. Someone hath set you on.
Confess the truth, and say by whose advice
Thou cam’st here to complain.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: And is this all?
Then, O you blessèd ministers above,
Keep me in patience, and with ripened time
Unfold the evil which is here wrapped up
In countenance. Heaven shield your Grace from woe,
As I, thus wronged, hence unbelievèd go.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: I know you’d fain be gone.— An officer!
To prison with her. Shall we thus permit
A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall
On him so near us? This needs must be a practice.—
Who knew of your intent and coming hither?

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: My lord, I know him. ’Tis a meddling friar.
I do not like the man. Had he been lay, my lord,
For certain words he spake against your Grace
In your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Words against me? This’ a good friar, belike.
And to set on this wretched woman here
Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar,
I saw them at the prison. A saucy friar,
A very scurvy fellow.

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: Blessed be your royal Grace.
I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard
Your royal ear abused. First hath this woman
Most wrongfully accused your substitute,
Who is as free from touch or soil with her
As she from one ungot.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: We did believe no less.
Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: I know him for a man divine and holy,
Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler,
As he’s reported by this gentleman;
And on my trust, a man that never yet
Did, as he vouches, misreport your Grace.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: My lord, most villainously, believe it.

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: Well, he in time may come to clear himself;
But at this instant he is sick, my lord,
Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request,
Being come to knowledge that there was complaint
Intended ’gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither
To speak as from his mouth, what he doth know
Is true and false, and what he with his oath
And all probation will make up full clear
Whensoever he’s convented. First, for this woman,
To justify this worthy nobleman,
So vulgarly and personally accused,
Her shall you hear disprovèd to her eyes
Till she herself confess it.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Good friar, let’s hear it.—
Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo?
O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools!—
Give us some seats.— Come, cousin Angelo,
In this I’ll be impartial. Be you judge
Of your own cause.
Is this the witness, friar?
First, let her show her face, and after speak.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Pardon, my lord, I will not show my face
Until my husband bid me.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Are you a maid?

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: A widow, then?

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.p: Neither, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Why you are nothing, then, neither maid, widow,
nor wife?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
My lord, she may be a punk, for many of them
are neither maid, widow, nor wife.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Silence that fellow. I would he had some cause
to prattle for himself.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: Well, my lord.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: My lord, I do confess I ne’er was married,
And I confess besides I am no maid.
I have known my husband, yet my husband
Knows not that ever he knew me.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: He was drunk, then, my lord; it can be no better.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so
too.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: Well, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Now I come to ’t, my lord.
She that accuses him of fornication
In selfsame manner doth accuse my husband,
And charges him, my lord, with such a time
When, I’ll depose, I had him in mine arms
With all th’ effect of love.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: Charges she more than me?

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Not that I know.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: No? You say your husband.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo,
Who thinks he knows that he ne’er knew my body,
But knows, he thinks, that he knows Isabel’s.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: This is a strange abuse. Let’s see thy face.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: My husband bids me. Now I will unmask.
This is that face, thou cruel Angelo,
Which once thou swor’st was worth the looking on.
This is the hand which, with a vowed contract,
Was fast belocked in thine. This is the body
That took away the match from Isabel
And did supply thee at thy garden house
In her imagined person.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Know you this woman?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: Carnally, she says.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Sirrah, no more.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: Enough, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: My lord, I must confess I know this woman,
And five years since there was some speech of marriage
Betwixt myself and her, which was broke off,
Partly for that her promisèd proportions
Came short of composition, but in chief
For that her reputation was disvalued
In levity. Since which time of five years
I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her,
Upon my faith and honor.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Noble prince,
As there comes light from heaven and words from breath,
As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue,
I am affianced this man’s wife as strongly
As words could make up vows. And, my good lord,
But Tuesday night last gone in ’s garden house
He knew me as a wife. As this is true,
Let me in safety raise me from my knees,
Or else forever be confixèd here
A marble monument.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: I did but smile till now.
Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice.
My patience here is touched. I do perceive
These poor informal women are no more
But instruments of some more mightier member
That sets them on. Let me have way, my lord,
To find this practice out.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Ay, with my heart,
And punish them to your height of pleasure.—
Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman,
Compact with her that’s gone, think’st thou thy oaths,
Though they would swear down each particular saint,
Were testimonies against his worth and credit
That’s sealed in approbation?— You, Lord Escalus,
Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains
To find out this abuse, whence ’tis derived.
sp.stage: The Duke rises. Escalus is seated.
sp.l: There is another friar that set them on.
Let him be sent for.

sp.speaker: FRIAR PETER
sp.l: Would he were here, my lord, for he indeed
Hath set the women on to this complaint;
Your provost knows the place where he abides,
And he may fetch him.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Go, do it instantly.
To Angelo. And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin,
Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth,
Do with your injuries as seems you best
In any chastisement. I for a while
Will leave you; but stir not you till you have
Well determined upon these slanderers.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: My lord, we’ll do it throughly.
sp.p:
Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar
Lodowick to be a dishonest person?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Cucullus non facit monachum, honest in nothing
but in his clothes, and one that hath spoke most
villainous speeches of the Duke.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
We shall entreat you to abide here till he
come, and enforce them against him. We shall find
this friar a notable fellow.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: As any in Vienna, on my word.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Call that same Isabel here once again. I would
speak with her.

To Angelo. Pray you, my lord, give me leave to
question. You shall see how I’ll handle her.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: Not better than he, by her own report.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: Say you?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately,
she would sooner confess; perchance publicly she’ll
be ashamed.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p: I will go darkly to work with her.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: That’s the way, for women are light at midnight.

div.stage: Enter Duke as a Friar, Provost, and Isabella, with Officers.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Come on, mistress. Here’s a gentlewoman
denies all that you have said.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of, here
with the Provost.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
In very good time. Speak not you to him till
we call upon you.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Come, sir, did you set
these women on to slander Lord Angelo? They have
confessed you did.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: ’Tis false.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: How? Know you where you are?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Respect to your great place, and let the devil
Be sometime honored for his burning throne.
Where is the Duke? ’Tis he should hear me speak.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: The Duke’s in us, and we will hear you speak.
Look you speak justly.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Boldly, at least.— But, O, poor souls,
Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox?
Good night to your redress. Is the Duke gone?
Then is your cause gone too. The Duke’s unjust
Thus to retort your manifest appeal,
And put your trial in the villain’s mouth
Which here you come to accuse.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: Why, thou unreverend and unhallowed friar,
Is ’t not enough thou hast suborned these women
To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth
And in the witness of his proper ear,
To call him villain? And then to glance from him
To th’ Duke himself, to tax him with injustice?—
Take him hence. To th’ rack with him. We’ll touse him
Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose.
What? “ Unjust”?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Be not so hot. The Duke
Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he
Dare rack his own. His subject am I not,
Nor here provincial. My business in this state
Made me a looker-on here in Vienna,
Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble
Till it o’errun the stew. Laws for all faults,
But faults so countenanced that the strong statutes
Stand like the forfeits in a barber’s shop,
As much in mock as mark.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: Slander to th’ state!
Away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio?
Is this the man that you did tell us of?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
’Tis he, my lord.— Come hither, Goodman Baldpate.
Do you know me?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
I remember you, sir, by the sound of
your voice. I met you at the prison in the absence of
the Duke.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
O, did you so? And do you remember what you
said of the Duke?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Most notedly, sir.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Do you so, sir? And was the Duke a fleshmonger,
a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to
be?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
You must, sir, change persons with me
ere you make that my report. You indeed spoke so
of him, and much more, much worse.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
O, thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by
the nose for thy speeches?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
I protest I love the Duke as I love
myself.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.p:
Hark how the villain would close now, after
his treasonable abuses!

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.p:
Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away
with him to prison. Where is the Provost?

Away with him to prison. Lay bolts
enough upon him. Let him speak no more. Away
with those giglets too, and with the other confederate
companion.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Stay, sir, stay awhile.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.p: What, resists he?— Help him, Lucio.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Come, sir, come, sir,
come, sir. Foh, sir! Why you bald-pated, lying rascal,
you must be hooded, must you? Show your knave’s
visage, with a pox to you! Show your sheep-biting
face, and be hanged an hour! Will ’t not off?

div.stage: He pulls off the friar’s hood, and reveals the Duke.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Thou art the first knave that e’er mad’st a duke.—
First, provost, let me bail these gentle three.
To Lucio. Sneak not away, sir, for the friar and you
Must have a word anon.— Lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.l: This may prove worse than hanging.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: What you have spoke I pardon. Sit you down.
We’ll borrow place of him. To Angelo. Sir, by your leave.
Hast thou or word, or wit, or impudence
That yet can do thee office? If thou hast,
Rely upon it till my tale be heard,
And hold no longer out.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: O my dread lord,
I should be guiltier than my guiltiness
To think I can be undiscernible,
When I perceive your Grace, like power divine,
Hath looked upon my passes. Then, good prince,
No longer session hold upon my shame,
But let my trial be mine own confession.
Immediate sentence then and sequent death
Is all the grace I beg.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Come hither, Mariana.
To Angelo. Say, wast thou e’er contracted to this woman?

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: I was, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Go take her hence and marry her instantly.
To Friar Peter. Do you the office, friar, which consummate,
Return him here again.— Go with him, provost.

div.stage: Angelo, Mariana, Friar Peter, and Provost exit.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonor
Than at the strangeness of it.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Come hither, Isabel.
Your friar is now your prince. As I was then
Advertising and holy to your business,
Not changing heart with habit, I am still
Attorneyed at your service.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: O, give me pardon
That I, your vassal, have employed and pained
Your unknown sovereignty.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: You are pardoned, Isabel.
And now, dear maid, be you as free to us.
Your brother’s death, I know, sits at your heart,
And you may marvel why I obscured myself,
Laboring to save his life, and would not rather
Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power
Than let him so be lost. O most kind maid,
It was the swift celerity of his death,
Which I did think with slower foot came on,
That brained my purpose. But peace be with him.
That life is better life past fearing death
Than that which lives to fear. Make it your comfort,
So happy is your brother.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: I do, my lord.

div.stage: Enter Angelo, Mariana, Friar Peter, and Provost.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: For this new-married man approaching here,
Whose salt imagination yet hath wronged
Your well-defended honor, you must pardon
For Mariana’s sake. But as he adjudged your brother—
Being criminal in double violation
Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach
Thereon dependent for your brother’s life—
The very mercy of the law cries out
Most audible, even from his proper tongue,
“ An Angelo for Claudio, death for death.”
Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure;
Like doth quit like, and measure still for measure.—
Then, Angelo, thy fault’s thus manifested,
Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage.
We do condemn thee to the very block
Where Claudio stooped to death, and with like haste.—
Away with him.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: O my most gracious lord,
I hope you will not mock me with a husband.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: It is your husband mocked you with a husband.
Consenting to the safeguard of your honor,
I thought your marriage fit. Else imputation,
For that he knew you, might reproach your life
And choke your good to come. For his possessions,
Although by confiscation they are ours,
We do instate and widow you with all
To buy you a better husband.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: O my dear lord,
I crave no other nor no better man.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Never crave him. We are definitive.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Gentle my liege—

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: You do but lose your labor.—
Away with him to death. To Lucio. Now, sir, to you.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: O, my good lord.— Sweet Isabel, take my part.
Lend me your knees, and all my life to come
I’ll lend you all my life to do you service.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Against all sense you do importune her.
Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact,
Her brother’s ghost his pavèd bed would break
And take her hence in horror.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Isabel,
Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me,
Hold up your hands, say nothing. I’ll speak all.
They say best men are molded out of faults,
And, for the most, become much more the better
For being a little bad. So may my husband.
O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: He dies for Claudio’s death.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA
sp.l: Most bounteous sir,
Look, if it please you, on this man condemned
As if my brother lived. I partly think
A due sincerity governed his deeds
Till he did look on me. Since it is so,
Let him not die. My brother had but justice,
In that he did the thing for which he died.
For Angelo,
His act did not o’ertake his bad intent,
And must be buried but as an intent
That perished by the way. Thoughts are no subjects,
Intents but merely thoughts.

sp.speaker: MARIANA
sp.l: Merely, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Your suit’s unprofitable. Stand up, I say.
I have bethought me of another fault.—
Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded
At an unusual hour?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: It was commanded so.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Had you a special warrant for the deed?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: No, my good lord, it was by private message.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: For which I do discharge you of your office.
Give up your keys.

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: Pardon me, noble lord.
I thought it was a fault, but knew it not,
Yet did repent me after more advice,
For testimony whereof, one in the prison
That should by private order else have died,
I have reserved alive.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: What’s he?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: His name is Barnardine.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio.
Go fetch him hither. Let me look upon him.

sp.speaker: ESCALUS
sp.l: I am sorry one so learnèd and so wise
As you, Lord Angelo, have still appeared,
Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood
And lack of tempered judgment afterward.

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure;
And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart
That I crave death more willingly than mercy.
’Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it.

div.stage: Enter Barnardine and Provost, Claudio, muffled, and Juliet.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Which is that Barnardine?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: This, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: There was a friar told me of this man.—
Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul
That apprehends no further than this world,
And squar’st thy life according. Thou ’rt condemned.
But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all,
And pray thee take this mercy to provide
For better times to come.— Friar, advise him.
I leave him to your hand.— What muffled fellow’s that?

sp.speaker: PROVOST
sp.l: This is another prisoner that I saved
Who should have died when Claudio lost his head,
As like almost to Claudio as himself.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: If he be like your brother, for his sake
Is he pardoned; and for your lovely sake,
Give me your hand and say you will be mine,
He is my brother too. But fitter time for that.
By this Lord Angelo perceives he’s safe;
Methinks I see a quick’ning in his eye.—
Well, Angelo, your evil quits you well.
Look that you love your wife, her worth worth yours.
I find an apt remission in myself.
And yet here’s one in place I cannot pardon.
To Lucio. You, sirrah, that knew me for a fool, a coward,
One all of luxury, an ass, a madman.
Wherein have I so deserved of you
That you extol me thus?

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Faith, my lord, I spoke it but according to the
trick. If you will hang me for it, you may, but I had
rather it would please you I might be whipped.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Whipped first, sir, and hanged after.—
Proclaim it, provost, round about the city,
If any woman wronged by this lewd fellow—
As I have heard him swear himself there’s one
Whom he begot with child— let her appear,
And he shall marry her. The nuptial finished,
Let him be whipped and hanged.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
I beseech your Highness do not marry me to a
whore. Your Highness said even now I made you a
duke. Good my lord, do not recompense me in
making me a cuckold.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Upon mine honor, thou shalt marry her.
Thy slanders I forgive and therewithal
Remit thy other forfeits.— Take him to prison,
And see our pleasure herein executed.

sp.speaker: LUCIO
sp.p:
Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death,
whipping, and hanging.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Slandering a prince deserves it.
She, Claudio, that you wronged, look you restore.—
Joy to you, Mariana.— Love her, Angelo.
I have confessed her, and I know her virtue.—
Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness.
There’s more behind that is more gratulate.—
Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy.
We shall employ thee in a worthier place.—
Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home
The head of Ragozine for Claudio’s.
Th’ offense pardons itself.— Dear Isabel,
I have a motion much imports your good,
Whereto if you’ll a willing ear incline,
What’s mine is yours, and what is yours is mine.—
So, bring us to our palace, where we’ll show
What’s yet behind that’s meet you all should know.
